title: A Brief History of the Modern-Day Straw, the World's Most Wasteful ...

readable_content:
Ernie Smith (2017-07-07): An estimated 500 million plastic straws are used by Americans every day. The environmental impact of plastic straws has sparked discussions about banning them, due to their contribution to ocean junk and harm to marine wildlife. The use of plastic straws has rapidly increased due to their convenience and durability compared to the biodegradable rye straws that were previously used. Marvin Stone, a serial inventor, introduced the paper straw as a solution to the shortcomings of the rye straw. Despite its initial popularity, the paper straw was eventually replaced by plastic straws, leading to significant environmental concerns. Alternative materials such as bamboo, metal, and corn have emerged as potential replacements for plastic straws, with a focus on biodegradability and sustainability. Additionally, edible straws such as cookie and candy straws, as well as ice straws, have gained attention as eco-friendly alternatives. The resurgence of paper straws has been attributed to environmental concerns linked to plastic straws.

- The text then discusses the influence and actions of Ted Turner, an eccentric billionaire, who is credited with contributing to the resurgence of paper straws with a billion-dollar donation to the United Nations.
summary: The text highlights the environmental impact of plastic straws and the potential for banning them due to their contribution to ocean junk and harm to marine wildlife. It also discusses the emergence of alternative materials, such as bamboo and metal, as potential replacements for plastic straws. Overall, the sentiment conveyed is in support of the movement to ban plastic straws and find more sustainable alternatives. Sentiment: 0.8
